Mean Absorption Coin Toss Problems

Jun 20, 2020 | coin  probability 

Overview

These problems appear as follows:

  • How many coin tosses would it take on average until we see 3 consecutive heads?
  • What is the expected number of coin flips until the first heads appears on an even flip?
  • What is the expected number of times a person must toss coins until the pattern HTHHTHHTH emerges?

In the above, we are asked to compute an expected waiting time until some sequence occurs, and in a given trial, this prescribed sequence will always occur after some number of coin tosses. Let’s use the first example problem, the waiting time until HHHHHHHHH, for the different methods of solving.

Using System of Equations

Expected Value

The expected value for a discrete random variable XXX is defined as the sum over all values that XXX can take multiplied by its probability of occurrence: E[X]=∑ixi×Pr[X=xi] \begin{aligned} \text{E}[X] &= \sum_{i} x_i \times \text{Pr}[X=x_i] \end{aligned} E[X]​=i∑​xi​×Pr[X=xi​]​ Let the discrete random variable XXX be defined as the number of coin tosses or flips until 3 consecutive heads appear. If we denote the probability of heads, Pr[H]=p\text{Pr}[H] = pPr[H]=p, and of tails, Pr[T]=q\text{Pr}[T] = qPr[T]=q, where p+q=1p+q=1p+q=1, then the expected number of flips until HHHHHHHHH appears is E[X]=3×Pr[X=3]⏞{HHH}+4×Pr[X=4]⏞{THHH}+5×Pr[X=5]⏞{TTHHH,HTHHH}+⋯=3p3+4qp3+5(q2p3+pqp3)+⋯\begin{aligned} \text{E}[X] &= \overbrace{3 \times \text{Pr}[X = 3]}^{\{HHH\}} + \overbrace{4 \times \text{Pr}[X = 4]}^{\{THHH\}}+ \overbrace{5 \times \text{Pr}[X = 5]}^{\{TTHHH, \hspace{0.5ex}HTHHH\}}+ \cdots\\ &= 3p^3 + 4qp^3 + 5(q^2p^3 + pqp^3) + \cdots\end{aligned}E[X]​=3×Pr[X=3]​{HHH}​+4×Pr[X=4]​{THHH}​+5×Pr[X=5]​{TTHHH,HTHHH}​+⋯=3p3+4qp3+5(q2p3+pqp3)+⋯​

Conditional Expectation

Instead of figuring out what this power series converges to, we can simplify our problem by rewriting the expected value conditioned on the variable YYY: E[X]=E[E[X∣Y]]=∑iPr[Y=yi]×E[X∣Y=yi] \begin{aligned} \text{E}[X] &= \text{E}[\text{E}[X|Y]]= \sum_{i}\text{Pr}[Y = y_i] \times \text{E}[X|Y=y_i] \end{aligned} E[X]​=E[E[X∣Y]]=i∑​Pr[Y=yi​]×E[X∣Y=yi​]​

We will define YYY as the possible outcomes of our first coin flip so that E[X]=Pr[Y=H]×E[X∣Y=H]+Pr[Y=T]×E[X∣Y=T] \begin{aligned} \text{E}[X] &= \text{Pr}[Y=H] \times \text{E}[X|Y=H] + \text{Pr}[Y=T] \times \text{E}[X|Y=T] \end{aligned} E[X]​=Pr[Y=H]×E[X∣Y=H]+Pr[Y=T]×E[X∣Y=T]​

If the first flip is HHH, then we’ve increased the number of flips by 1 and the remaining flips left can be defined as E[X∣H]\text{E}[X|H]E[X∣H], a quantity that is conditioned on the fact we just flipped HHH. But if the next flip is TTT, then we’ve also increased the number of flips by 1. However, the remaining flips left, E[X∣T]=E[X]\text{E}[X|T]=\text{E}[X]E[X∣T]=E[X] because flipping TTT does not get us further along towards HHHHHHHHH. Therefore, E[X∣Y=H]=1+E[X∣H]E[X∣Y=T]=1+E[X] \begin{aligned} \text{E}[X|Y=H] &= 1 + \text{E}[X|H]\\ \text{E}[X|Y=T] &= 1 + \text{E}[X] \end{aligned} E[X∣Y=H]E[X∣Y=T]​=1+E[X∣H]=1+E[X]​ In addition, Pr[Y=H]=Pr[H]\text{Pr}[Y=H] = \text{Pr}[H]Pr[Y=H]=Pr[H] and Pr[Y=T]=Pr[T]\text{Pr}[Y=T] = \text{Pr}[T]Pr[Y=T]=Pr[T] because the individual coin tosses are independent. In other words, probability of heads or tails does not change depending on the toss number.

General Form

Using the same logic to write E[X∣H]\text{E}[X|H]E[X∣H] and E[X∣HH]\text{E}[X|HH]E[X∣HH] as conditional expectations, our equations are E[X]=p(1+E[X∣H])+q(1+E[X])E[X∣H]=p(1+E[X∣HH])+q(1+E[X])E[X∣HH]=p(1+E[X∣HHH])+q(1+E[X])\begin{aligned} \text{E}[X] &= p(1+\text{E}[X|H]) + q(1+\text{E}[X])\\ \text{E}[X|H] &= p(1+\text{E}[X|HH]) + q(1+\text{E}[X])\\ \text{E}[X|HH] &= p(1+\text{E}[X|HHH]) + q(1+\text{E}[X]) \end{aligned}E[X]E[X∣H]E[X∣HH]​=p(1+E[X∣H])+q(1+E[X])=p(1+E[X∣HH])+q(1+E[X])=p(1+E[X∣HHH])+q(1+E[X])​ where E[X∣HHH]=0\text{E}[X|HHH]=0E[X∣HHH]=0 because no more flips are needed if we’ve already gotten HHHHHHHHH. Using p+q=1p+q=1p+q=1 and rearranging our unknowns and constants gives pE[X]−pE[X∣H]+0=1−qE[X]+E[X∣H]−pE[X∣HH]=1−qE[X]+0+E[X∣HH]=1}[p−p0−q1−p−q01][E[X]E[X∣H]E[X∣HH]]=[111]\begin{aligned} \left. \begin{alignedat}{4} p\text{E}[X] & {}-{} p& {}\text{E}[X|H]{} & {}+{} & 0 & = 1 \\ -q \text{E}[X] & {}+{} & {}\text{E}[X|H]{} & {}-{} p&\text{E}[X|HH] & = 1 \\ -q\text{E}[X] & {}+{} & {}0{} & {}+{} &\text{E}[X|HH] & = 1 \end{alignedat} \right\} \quad \begin{bmatrix} p & -p & 0\\ -q & 1 & -p\\ -q & 0 & 1 \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} \text{E}[X]\\ \text{E}[X|H]\\ \text{E}[X|HH]\\ \end{bmatrix}= \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1\\ 1\\ \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned}pE[X]−qE[X]−qE[X]​−p++​E[X∣H]E[X∣H]0​+−p+​0E[X∣HH]E[X∣HH]​=1=1=1​⎭⎪⎪⎬⎪⎪⎫​⎣⎢⎡​p−q−q​−p10​0−p1​⎦⎥⎤​⎣⎢⎡​E[X]E[X∣H]E[X∣HH]​⎦⎥⎤​=⎣⎢⎡​111​⎦⎥⎤​​ For a fair coin, p=q=1/2p=q=1/2p=q=1/2, [E[X]E[X∣H]E[X∣HH]]=[1/2−1/20−1/21−1/2−1/201]−1[111]=[842642422][111]=[14128]\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} \text{E}[X]\\ \text{E}[X|H]\\ \text{E}[X|HH]\\ \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 1/2 & -1/2 & 0\\ -1/2 & 1 & -1/2\\ -1/2 & 0 & 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}^{-1} \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1\\ 1\\ \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 8 & 4 & 2\\ 6 & 4 & 2\\ 4 & 2 & 2 \\ \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1\\ 1\\ \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 14\\ 12\\ 8\\ \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned}⎣⎢⎡​E[X]E[X∣H]E[X∣HH]​⎦⎥⎤​=⎣⎢⎡​1/2−1/2−1/2​−1/210​0−1/21​⎦⎥⎤​−1⎣⎢⎡​111​⎦⎥⎤​=⎣⎢⎡​864​442​222​⎦⎥⎤​⎣⎢⎡​111​⎦⎥⎤​=⎣⎢⎡​14128​⎦⎥⎤​​ Therefore, the expected number of flips before obtaining HHHHHHHHH is 14. If we start with HHHHHH already, then the expected number of flips remaining becomes 8. By conditioning on the first move, we’ve actually used something called first step analysis to solve this problem. This technique finds many applications in problems that involve finding mean absorption times. Keep in mind the matrix inversion operation above as it will soon make another appearance!

Markov Chain

Probability of being in given state

From the first step analysis, after any nnnth toss, the coin flip pattern can be in one of 4 states:

  • S0S_0S0​: the previous flip was not HHH or we haven’t flipped anything yet (n=0n=0n=0)
  • S1S_1S1​: the previous flip was HHH
  • S2S_2S2​: the previous two flips were HHHHHH
  • S3S_3S3​: the previous three flips were HHHHHHHHH

Let’s define a probability distribution vector, x(n)\mathbf{x}(n)x(n), where the iiith entry denotes the probability of being in state SiS_iSi​ on the nnnth flip. Before we’ve flipped anything, n=0n=0n=0, there’s a 100% chance we are in S0S_0S0​. After n=1n=1n=1, there is a Pr[H]=p\text{Pr}[H]=pPr[H]=p we are in S1S_1S1​ and a Pr[T]=q\text{Pr}[T]=qPr[T]=q we remain in S0S_0S0​: x(0)=[1000],x(1)=[qp00] \begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}(0) = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0\\ 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}, \quad \mathbf{x}(1) = \begin{bmatrix} q \\ p\\ 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned}x(0)=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​1000​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​,x(1)=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​qp00​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​​

Transition Matrix

What about for n=2n=2n=2 and so forth? Let’s define a matrix A\mathbf{A}A of iii rows and jjj columns where each entry aija_{ij}aij​ is the probability of moving into SjS_jSj​ on flip n+1n+1n+1 given that we started in SiS_iSi​ on flip nnn: A=[qp00q0p0q00p0001] \begin{aligned} \mathbf{A} = \begin{bmatrix} q & p & 0 & 0 \\ q & 0 & p & 0 \\ q & 0 & 0 & p \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned} A=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​qqq0​p000​0p00​00p1​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​​ Thus, where the chain can go next depends only on where it was in the previous state. From the law of total probability, each row of this transition matrix must sum to 1.

We can use this matrix to calculate the probability distribution of being in each state on flip n+1n+1n+1 given our distribution on flip nnn: A⋅x(n)=x(n+1)\begin{aligned} \mathbf{A}\cdot \mathbf{x}(n) &= \mathbf{x}(n+1) \end{aligned}A⋅x(n)​=x(n+1)​

While A\mathbf{A}A gives us the probability of transitions in 1 successive flip, what if we wanted to know the probability of going from SiS_iSi​ to SjS_jSj​ in exactly n>1n > 1n>1 successive flips? It turns out that raising A\mathbf{A}A to the power nnn produces those nnn-step transition probabilities. Thus, An⋅x(0)=x(n)\begin{aligned} \mathbf{A}^n \cdot \mathbf{x}(0) = \mathbf{x}(n) \end{aligned}An⋅x(0)=x(n)​

Existence of an Absorbing State

Is it true that if coins were flipped forever, we would eventually get HHHHHHHHH? That is, as we flip coins forever, the probability distribution vector will converge will all the mass in S3S_3S3​: lim⁡n→∞Anx(0)=lim⁡n→∞x(n)=[0001]\begin{aligned} \lim_{n\to \infty}\mathbf{A}^n \mathbf{x}(0) = \lim_{n\to \infty}\mathbf{x}(n) = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0\\ 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned}n→∞lim​Anx(0)=n→∞lim​x(n)=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​0001​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​​

Let us recall how eigenvalues and eigenvectors are related for a matrix, Av=λv\begin{aligned} \mathbf{A}\mathbf{v} &= \lambda \mathbf{v} \end{aligned}Av​=λv​ If we calculate the eigenvalues of A\mathbf{A}A, we find the largest eigenvalue to be 1. In fact, the Perron-Frobenius Theorem states that stochastic matrices will always contain λmax=1\lambda_{\text{max}} = 1λmax​=1. This means the eigenvector associated with λ=1\lambda = 1λ=1 fulfills Av=v\mathbf{A}\mathbf{v} = \mathbf{v}Av=v. This eigenvector turns out to be v=[0,0,0,1]T\mathbf{v} = [0, 0, 0, 1]^Tv=[0,0,0,1]T! Put another way, when x(n)=v\mathbf{x}(n) = \mathbf{v}x(n)=v, the Markov Chain has been absorbed, A⋅x(n)=x(n)\mathbf{A} \cdot \mathbf{x}(n) = \mathbf{x}(n)A⋅x(n)=x(n).

Fundamental Matrix

For absorbing Markov Chains, we can partition the transition matrix into 4 quadrants: A=[qp00q0p0q00p0001]=[QR0I] \begin{aligned} \def\arraystretch{1.2} \mathbf{A} = \left[ \begin{array}{ccc|c} q & p & 0 & 0 \\ q & 0 & p & 0 \\ q & 0 & 0 & p \\ \hline 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{c|c} \mathbf{Q} & \mathbf{R} \\ \hline \mathbf{0} & \mathbf{I} \end{array}\right] \end{aligned} A=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎡​qqq0​p000​0p00​00p1​​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎤​=[Q0​RI​​]​

  • Q\mathbf{Q}Q is a square matrix with probabilities (all less than 1) between transient states
  • R\mathbf{R}R is a rectangular matrix of probabilities (all less than 1) between transient to absorbing states
  • 0\mathbf{0}0 is a rectangular matrix denoting transitions between states that never happen (cannot go from S3S_3S3​ to any state other than itself)
  • I\mathbf{I}I is the identity matrix of absorbing states

For different powers of A\mathbf{A}A, A2=[Q2(Q+I)R0I],A3=[Q3(Q2+Q+I)R0I],An=[Qn(∑i=0n−1Qi)R0I]\begin{aligned} \mathbf{A}^2 &= \begin{bmatrix} \mathbf{Q}^2 & (\mathbf{Q}+\mathbf{I})\mathbf{R}\\ \mathbf{0} & \mathbf{I} \end{bmatrix}, \quad \mathbf{A}^3 = \begin{bmatrix} \mathbf{Q}^3 & (\mathbf{Q}^2 + \mathbf{Q}+\mathbf{I})\mathbf{R}\\ \mathbf{0} & \mathbf{I} \end{bmatrix}, \quad \mathbf{A}^n = \begin{bmatrix} \mathbf{Q}^n & (\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} \mathbf{Q}^i)\mathbf{R}\\ \mathbf{0} & \mathbf{I} \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned}A2​=[Q20​(Q+I)RI​],A3=[Q30​(Q2+Q+I)RI​],An=[Qn0​(∑i=0n−1​Qi)RI​]​

What happens as nnn goes to ∞\infty∞? lim⁡n→∞An=[0(I−Q)−1R0I]\begin{aligned} \lim_{n \to \infty} \mathbf{A}^n = \begin{bmatrix} \mathbf{0} & (\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{Q})^{-1}\mathbf{R}\\ \mathbf{0}& \mathbf{I} \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned}n→∞lim​An=[00​(I−Q)−1RI​]​ where we’ve used the fact that all the entries of Q\mathbf{Q}Q are less than 0 so they should get smaller as nnn grows bigger. Let’s take a closer look at what goes on the upper right corner. Let’s define a matrix N\mathbf{N}N as N=∑i=0∞QiQN=∑i=0∞Qi+1N−QN=IN=(I−Q)−1\begin{aligned} \mathbf{N} &= \sum_{i=0}^\infty \mathbf{Q}^i\\ \mathbf{Q}\mathbf{N} &= \sum_{i=0}^\infty \mathbf{Q}^{i+1}\\ \mathbf{N} - \mathbf{Q}\mathbf{N} &= \mathbf{I}\\ \mathbf{N} &= (\mathbf{I}- \mathbf{Q})^{-1} \end{aligned}NQNN−QNN​=i=0∑∞​Qi=i=0∑∞​Qi+1=I=(I−Q)−1​

This is known as the fundamental matrix, and it’s something we’ve seen before! Recall the matrix inversion that would make a reappearance: N=([p−p0−q1−p−q01]⏟system of equations)−1=([100010001]⏟I−[qp0q0pq00]⏟Q)−1\begin{aligned} \mathbf{N} = \left(\underbrace{\begin{bmatrix} p & -p & 0\\ -q & 1 & -p\\ -q & 0 & 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}}_{\text{system of equations}}\right)^{-1} = \left(\underbrace{\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0\\ 0 & 1 & 0\\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}}_{\mathbf{I}} - \underbrace{\begin{bmatrix} q & p & 0\\ q & 0 & p\\ q & 0 & 0 \\ \end{bmatrix}}_{\mathbf{Q}}\right)^{-1} \end{aligned}N=⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​system of equations⎣⎢⎡​p−q−q​−p10​0−p1​⎦⎥⎤​​​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​−1=⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​I⎣⎢⎡​100​010​001​⎦⎥⎤​​​−Q⎣⎢⎡​qqq​p00​0p0​⎦⎥⎤​​​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​−1​

As before, for a fair coin, N=[842642422] \begin{aligned}\mathbf{N}= \begin{bmatrix} 8 & 4 & 2\\ 6 & 4 & 2\\ 4 & 2 & 2 \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned} N=⎣⎢⎡​864​442​222​⎦⎥⎤​​

Each entry in N\mathbf{N}N contains the expected number of visits that starting in SiS_iSi​ the chain visits SjS_jSj​. Since the chain has to progress through S0S_0S0​, S1S_1S1​, and S2S_2S2​ before it arrives at the absorbing state S3S_3S3​, the expected number of flips to get to S3S_3S3​ starting from S0S_0S0​ is the sum of the first row, (N⋅1)0(\mathbf{N}\cdot \mathbf{1})_0(N⋅1)0​.

Equivalency to Powers of Q\mathbf{Q}Q

There is another way to understand what each entry nijn_{ij}nij​ describes. Let us define the random variable XijnX_{ij}^nXijn​ which equals

  • 1 if the chain ends up in SjS_jSj​ after exactly nnn flips starting from SiS_iSi​
  • 0 otherwise

Furthermore, since we know for some Qn\mathbf{Q}^nQn that qijnq_{ij}^nqijn​ is the probability the chain transitions from SiS_iSi​ to SjS_jSj​ in exactly nnn flips, we have Pr[Xijn=1]=qijnPr[Xijn=0]=1−qijn\begin{aligned} \text{Pr}[X_{ij}^n = 1] &= q_{ij}^n\\ \text{Pr}[X_{ij}^n = 0] &= 1-q_{ij}^n \end{aligned}Pr[Xijn​=1]Pr[Xijn​=0]​=qijn​=1−qijn​​ The expected number of time (not plural since it can’t finish up there more than once!) that the chain will end up in SjS_jSj​ after exactly nnn tosses starting from SiS_iSi​ is E[Xijn]=1×Pr[Xijn=1]+0×Pr[Xijn=0]=qijn\begin{aligned} \text{E}[X_{ij}^n] &= 1 \times \text{Pr}[X_{ij}^n = 1] + 0 \times \text{Pr}[X_{ij}^n = 0]\\ &= q_{ij}^n \end{aligned}E[Xijn​]​=1×Pr[Xijn​=1]+0×Pr[Xijn​=0]=qijn​​ Thus, the expected number of times the chain will end up in SjS_jSj​ for all values of tosses from 000 to ∞\infty∞ given that we start from SiS_iSi​ is E[Xij0+Xij1+Xij2+…]=E[Xij0]+E[Xij1]+E[Xij2]+…=qij0+qij1+qij2+…=nij\begin{aligned} \text{E}[X_{ij}^0 + X_{ij}^1 + X_{ij}^2 + \ldots] &= \text{E}[X_{ij}^0] + \text{E}[X_{ij}^1] + \text{E}[X_{ij}^2] +\ldots\\ &= q_{ij}^0 + q_{ij}^1 + q_{ij}^2 + \ldots \\&= n_{ij} \end{aligned}E[Xij0​+Xij1​+Xij2​+…]​=E[Xij0​]+E[Xij1​]+E[Xij2​]+…=qij0​+qij1​+qij2​+…=nij​​ where qij0=1q_{ij}^0 = 1qij0​=1 only if j=ij=ij=i since if we start in iii and no tosses happen, we still remain in state iii. As shown above, we can also arrive at an intuitive understanding of the entries of N\mathbf{N}N from the sum over all powers of Q\mathbf{Q}Q.

Absorbing Probabilities

The complete expression at the upper right corner of the partitioned matrix, NR\mathbf{N}\mathbf{R}NR, is a 3×13\times 13×1 rectangular matrix where each entry is the probability of absorption given the chain starts in one of the transient states. NR=[842642422][001/2]=[111] \mathbf{N}\mathbf{R} = \begin{bmatrix} 8 & 4 & 2\\ 6 & 4 & 2\\ 4 & 2 & 2 \\ \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0\\ 1/2\\ \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \\ \end{bmatrix} NR=⎣⎢⎡​864​442​222​⎦⎥⎤​⎣⎢⎡​001/2​⎦⎥⎤​=⎣⎢⎡​111​⎦⎥⎤​ Since we only have one absorbing state, there is only one column, and the probabilities of being absorbed are all 100%. If instead, the problem contained a second absorbing state, then we could compare the probabilities of being absorbed into the different absorbing state.

Probability Generating Function

If we flip coins forever, we will eventually reach 3 consecutive heads. But what could we say about all the coin flip patterns before the HHHHHHHHH? HHT∣T∣T∣HT⋯HHHT∣HT∣T⋯HHHT∣T∣T⋯HHHHT∣HHT⋯HHH\begin{aligned}&HHT|T|T|HT\cdots HHH\\ &T|HT|T\cdots HHH\\ &T|T|T\cdots HHH\\ &HT|HHT\cdots HHH\end{aligned}​HHT∣T∣T∣HT⋯HHHT∣HT∣T⋯HHHT∣T∣T⋯HHHHT∣HHT⋯HHH​ Notice that we could break them up into 3 chunks:

  • one or more consecutive TTTs
  • a single HHH followed by a single TTT,
  • two HHHs followed by a single TTT

and of course there must be the HHHHHHHHH at the end. Therefore, any sequence is of the form (T,HT,HHT)HHH(T, HT, HHT)HHH(T,HT,HHT)HHH where each subsequence in the parentheses can be repeated 0 or as many times as possible, in any order, and with each other. Also notice that any combination of these building blocks will not produce 3 consecutive heads. With a probability generating function (PGF), we can generate all the probabilities of the distribution: GX(z)=∑k∞Pr(X=k)×zkG_X(z) = \sum_k^\infty \text{Pr}(X=k) \times z^kGX​(z)=k∑∞​Pr(X=k)×zk The variable zzz is considered a dummy variable whose purpose is to allow the function GGG to represent the entire probability distribution. To see why, when z=1z=1z=1, we are just adding up all the probabilities of outcomes of the random variable XXX and GX(1)=1G_X(1) = 1GX​(1)=1.

Method of Moments

The powers of zzz denote the values our random variable XXX can take. In this case, it would be the number of coin tosses. Its coefficients reflect the probabilities of occurrence. If one takes the first derivative of the function evaluated at z=1z=1z=1, GX′(1)=∑k∞k×Pr[X=k]=E[X]G_X'(1) = \sum_k^\infty k \times \text{Pr}[X=k] = \text{E}[X]GX′​(1)=k∑∞​k×Pr[X=k]=E[X] and we recover the formula for expected value. Thus, the first moment of a PGF gives the expectation. We can even calculate the variance with the second derivative like so Var[X]=G′′(1)+GX′(1)−[GX′(1)]2\text{Var}[X] = G''(1)+G_X'(1)-[G_X'(1)]^2Var[X]=G′′(1)+GX′​(1)−[GX′​(1)]2. Our generating function for XXX is GX(z)=∑k∞(qz+pqz2+p2qz3⏞(T,HT,HHT))kp3z3⏞HHH=p3z31−(qz+pqz2+p2qz3)\begin{aligned}G_X(z) &= \sum_k^\infty (\overbrace{qz+pqz^2+p^2qz^3}^{(T,\hspace{0.5ex} HT,\hspace{0.5ex} HHT)})^k\overbrace{p^3z^3}^{HHH}\\ &= \frac{p^3 z^3}{1- (qz+pqz^2+p^2qz^3)}\end{aligned}GX​(z)​=k∑∞​(qz+pqz2+p2qz3​(T,HT,HHT)​)kp3z3​HHH​=1−(qz+pqz2+p2qz3)p3z3​​ For a fair coin, p=q=1/2p=q=1/2p=q=1/2, the first derivative evaluated at z=1z=1z=1 is GX′(1)=(1−q−pq−p2q)3p3−p3(−q−2pq−3p2q)(1−q−pq−p2q)2=1/8×3/8+1/8×11/8(1/8)2=14 \begin{aligned} G_X'(1) &= \frac{(1-q-pq-p^2q)3p^3 - p^3 (-q -2pq -3p^2q)}{(1-q-pq-p^2q)^2} \\ &= \frac{1/8 \times 3/8 + 1/8 \times 11/8}{(1/8)^2} = 14 \end{aligned}GX′​(1)​=(1−q−pq−p2q)2(1−q−pq−p2q)3p3−p3(−q−2pq−3p2q)​=(1/8)21/8×3/8+1/8×11/8​=14​

When to Use Which?

For simple formulations of mean absorption problems, I find the first step method with the system of equations to be the most intuitive approach. Being able to deconstruct the problem into a conditional expectation also is a straight-forward thought process I find. With the Markov approach, having to invert (I−Q)−1(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{Q})^{-1}(I−Q)−1 to get the fundamental matrix without a computer is pretty annoying especially when the matrix is larger than 3×33 \times 33×3. However, when the problem is messy enough, a computer is almost always needed unless there’s a trick. The PGF approach gives a nice formula for the entire distribution but derivatives can also be a pain to do when the problem becomes more complex.

One nice extension of the Markov method is that when there are multiple absorbing states, and the problem additionally asks for the relative probabilities of ending up in one state versus the other, you can easily calculate this from NR\mathbf{N}\mathbf{R}NR; for example, if the problem asks what the probability of getting HTHHTHHTH before HHTHHTHHT is. I’ll continue to share interesting coin flip problems!
